title: From Print Volumes to Digital Scholarship: The Handbook of Latin American Studies Web Archive

creator: Tracee Haupt Fugate

title: Anywhere Adventures is Hitting the Road!
content:
We’re on the hunt for two U.S. communities to include in Vivian Li’s Innovator in Residence Project, Anywhere Adventures! 

Visitors to the mobile experience are currently able to explore three American communities, Seattle, Chicago, and Southeastern Wyoming, through items from the Library’s digital collections and learn about the stories, people, and events that shaped everyday life in these places.
creator: Isabel Brador
sourceDescription: Digital Happenings at the Library of Congress

title: Web Archiving at the Library After 25 Years
content:
This post is co-written by Abbie Grotke (Section Head), Amanda Lehman (Digital Collections Specialist), and Melissa Wertheimer (Senior Digital Collections Specialist) of the Web Archiving Section to close our 25th-anniversary celebration year with some highlights of the program.

We Have a History

In 2025 we wrapped up our 25th year of web archiving at the Library of Congress! We also ended the year with over 100 web archive collections available online. The program has matured even since we celebrated our 20th anniversary in 2020. We can illustrate our history through the very objects
creator: Melissa Wertheimer
sourceDescription: Digital Happenings at the Library of Congress

title: What’s New Online at the Library of Congress: January 2026
content: Interested in learning more about what’s new in the Library of Congress digital collections? The Signal shares regular updates to our digital collections and we love showing off our colleagues’ hard work from across the Library. Read on for a sample of recent additions and a few favorite highlights. Click here for all previous updates.
creator: Carlyn Osborn
sourceDescription: Digital Happenings at the Library of Congress

title: Understanding AI at the Library: An Interview with Kurt Lemai-Nguyen
content:
In this interview, 2025 Library of Congress Junior Fellow Kurt Lemai-Nguyen reflects on his experience working to support understanding AI at the Library in the Library’s Digital Strategy Directorate. This interview has been edited for length and clarity.

title: File Format Flair for the Holidays!  Updates to the Sustainability of Digital Formats
content:
Today’s guest post is from Kate Murray, Liz Caringola, Genevieve Havemeyer-King and Liz Holdzkom of the Digital Collections Management & Services Division at the Library of Congress.

Happy new and updated FDDs (format description documents) to all who celebrate! It’s time for one of our favorite holiday traditions – an update about recent file format research and documentation from your friends (elves?) behind the Sustainability of Digital Formats! This is the ninth entry in the File Format Frien
creator: Liz Holdzkom
sourceDescription: Digital Happenings at the Library of Congress

title: Anywhere Adventures is Live!
content:
This post is the third in a series about the Library’s 2025 Innovator in Residence, Vivian Li, and her project Anywhere Adventures. Following the selection of three communities, and a visit to the Library for research, the mobile experience has now officially launched!  

The 2025 Inn
creator: Isabel Brador
sourceDescription: Digital Happenings at the Library of Congress

title: Where Science Meets Storytelling: Twelve Years of the Science Blogs Web Archive
content:
More than a decade after its launch, the Science Blogs Web Archive continues to grow and evolve. In this interview, Jennifer “JJ” Harbster reflects on building and maintaining the collection, while intern Yahir Brito brings a fresh perspective on updating and expanding it. Together, they share a few of their favorite blogs and discuss why it is important to preserve these unique examples of scientific communication.

First, let’s introduce both of you to the readers. Who are you and what was your role in creating this collection?
creator: Tracee Haupt Fugate
sourceDescription: Digital Happenings at the Library of Congress

title: Putting the American Revolution in Context Through Transcription
content:
Today’s guest post is from Lauren Algee, a Senior Digital Collections Specialist & By the People community manager at the Library of Congress.

What do patriotic songs, society women’s diaries, and nautical maps have in common? All give context to life in America before, during, and after the Revolutionary War – and you’re invited to transcribe them all with the By the People volunteer transcription program in commemoration of the 250th anniversary of American independence!

Since 2018, By the People has i
creator: Carlyn Osborn
sourceDescription: Digital Happenings at the Library of Congress
